definition of the global DoFs *We want to emphasize that the shape functions are constructed on each not on the reference cell only Usual finite elements are defined based on a parametric concept It means that a function space for a finite element is defined on one reference and it is transformed into each cell via a mapping from the reference cell However the P1 nonconforming element does not follow such concept It defines a function space with linear shape functions on each cell without any help of a function space on the reference cell In other the element is defined in real not via a mapping from a reference cell In it is similar to the FE_DGPNonparametric element *Thus this implementation does not have to compute shape values on the reference cell the shape values are computed by construction of the shape functions on each cell independently *We next have to consider the[1.x.9] basis functions for the element because the system of equations which we ultimately have to solve is for a global not local The global basis functions associated with a node are defined by a cell wise composition of shape functions associated with the node on each element *There is a theoretical result about the linear independence of the global basis functions depending on the type of the boundary condition we consider *When homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions are the global basis functions associated with interior nodes are linearly independent the number of DoFs is equal to the number of interior and consequently the same as the number of DoFs for the standard bilinear[2.x.23] finite element *When Neumann boundary conditions are the global basis functions associated with all nodes (including boundary nodes) are actually not linearly independent. we ultimately have to solve is for a global not local The global basis functions associated with a node are defined by a cell wise composition of shape functions associated with the node on each element* There is a theoretical result about the linear independence of the global basis functions depending on the type of the boundary condition we consider* When homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions are the global basis functions associated with interior nodes are linearly independent the number of DoFs is equal to the number of interior and consequently the same as the number of DoFs for the standard bilinear [2.x.23] finite element* When Neumann boundary conditions are the global basis functions associated with all nodes ( including boundary  nodes)
